title: How to Do Great at Animal Crossing (GameCube)

steps.headline: Finish working for Tom Nook.
steps.description: Keep the work uniform after you've finished working and sell the other clothes you have to him. Sell all your other items to him if you'd like. Soon, you can make the money to buy better items.

steps.headline: Buy the shovel, net, and fishing rod (you may have to wait for different days to buy them).
Make bells.
steps.description:
There are many simple methods - these include, but are not limited to: 
Digging up strange spots in the ground and selling what you find
Selling fossils, shells, fish, and insects
Doing work for the villagers
Selling lost and found items

steps.headline: Go to all the random town happenings you can.
steps.description: You often will score unique items from the mayor or the unique character.

steps.headline: Write to your villagers!
steps.description: Keep the messages simple and send them a small gift, like an apple. Try mentioning your gift in your message - the result may be a gift back and a better message (e.g. Here is a nice apple for you.) Also, it seems that using the animal's catch phrase helps.

text:
Finish working for Tom Nook. Keep the work uniform after you've finished working and sell the other clothes you have to him. Sell all your other items to him if you'd like. Soon, you can make the money to buy better items. Buy the shovel, net, and fishing rod (you may have to wait for different days to buy them).  Make bells. There are many simple methods - these include, but are not limited to: 
Digging up strange spots in the ground and selling what you find
Selling fossils, shells, fish, and insects
Doing work for the villagers
Selling lost and found items Go to all the random town happenings you can. You often will score unique items from the mayor or the unique character. Write to your villagers! Keep the messages simple and send them a small gift, like an apple. Try mentioning your gift in your message - the result may be a gift back and a better message (e.g. Here is a nice apple for you.) Also, it seems that using the animal's catch phrase helps.
